title.narrative: Biological Control of Pests in Mekong Eucalypt Plantations

description.narrative: The gall wasp (Leptocybe invasa), an Australian-origin insect pest, is threatening the viability and sustainability of the expanding eucalypt plantations in the Mekong Region. This project aims to investigate biological control options to overcome losses caused by the wasp and enhance the productivity of eucalypt plantations, directly benefiting plantation growers, communities and smallholder farmers. Research will determine the distribution and economic impacts of the gall wasp in this region. It will identify and test the effectiveness of potential biological control agents in quarantine and field sites, to control the pest and promote sustainable forestry. The project will also involve regional workshops to develop strategic and operational plans, and training activities and materials on techniques for control agent release, monitoring and dissemination.
